sentences: LeToya Nicole Luckett (born March 11, 1981) is an American singer-songwriter and actress.

== Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: In 1993, Luckett joined Beyoncé Knowles, LaTavia Roberson, and Kelly Rowland to complete the Houston-based R&B group, Destiny's Child.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: The roles of the group consisted with Knowles as lead vocalist, Rowland as second-lead vocalist alongside Roberson and Luckett as background vocalists with Roberson as alto (and spokesperson) adding the low notes and Luckett as the soprano adding the high notes to the group's harmony, with occasional leads too.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: After being signed and later dropped by Elektra Records in 1995, the group began working with D'wayne Wiggins and eventually signed with Columbia Records in 1997, but not before signing with group manager Mathew Knowles, Beyoncé's father.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: According to the E! Television Special, Boulevard of Broken Dreams, Mathew forced the girls to sign management agreements with him before they could sign with the label.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: Luckett's mother requested the contracts be reviewed by an attorney, but Mathew denied this request.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: However, Luckett eventually signed with him and joined the group.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: After graduating from the Houston club scene, the group opened for established acts such as Dru Hill, SWV, and Immature, was included on the Men in Black movie soundtrack, and released their 1998 self-titled debut album Destiny's Child.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: The album spawned two singles: the platinum "No, No, No Part II" (featuring Wyclef Jean) and "With Me".
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: Subsequently, the group made it on the soundtrack album of the romantic drama Why Do Fools Fall in Love with the song "Get on the Bus" (featuring Timbaland), and later toured as an opening act on TLC's "Fanmail Tour".
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: In 1999, the group released their second album, The Writing's on the Wall.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: The album became one of the biggest selling albums released by a female group, and was certified eight times platinum in the USA.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: As opposed to the first album, Luckett had more contribution to the second album in terms of co-writing.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: The album spawned four hit singles: "Bills, Bills, Bills", "Bug a Boo", "Say My Name", and "Jumpin' Jumpin'".
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: The two singles "Bills, Bills, Bills" and "Say My Name" were also nominated for Grammy awards, which "Say My Name" won in two different categories.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: The album had also been released in a "Houston Special Edition" which included a bonus track, where Luckett sung lead along with the other members, titled "Can't Help Myself".
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: In late 1999, in the midst of the group's success and rise, Luckett and Roberson asserted that they wanted their own manager because of the increasing lack of communication with manager Mathew Knowles.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: The pair said they never wanted to fire Knowles, but wanted to secure outside management to represent them.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: Soon after, Luckett and Roberson found themselves ostracized by the Knowles family and the group's management.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: When the music video for "Say My Name" debuted in February 2000, they were replaced by two new members, Michelle Williams and Farrah Franklin.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: Luckett and Roberson filed a lawsuit against Mathew, Beyoncé, and Kelly, charging them with breach of partnership and fiduciary duties, and sought unspecified damages.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: Luckett and Roberson withdrew the case against Beyoncé and Kelly, but continued to sue Mathew.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: The case was eventually settled, with Luckett and Roberson receiving royalties for their contributions as founding members of the group.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: Shortly following the release of Destiny's Child's Survivor, Luckett and Roberson filed another lawsuit against the group in March 2002.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: They claimed that the album's lead single, "Survivor", violated their previous settlement due to its lyrics.
section: == Early life and music career == | === 1993–2000: Destiny's Child and departure ===

sentences: The case was again settled out of court.

sentences: Acting career ==
section: == Acting career ==

sentences: Luckett's first role on television was on the WB show Smart Guy in 1998 with Destiny's Child.
section: == Acting career ==

sentences: She also had an appearance in the movie Beverly Hood in 1999.
section: == Acting career ==

sentences: Luckett has been a student at Tasha Smith's acting workshop.
section: == Acting career ==

sentences: Since 2008, Luckett has been acting in plays, television and movies.
section: == Acting career ==

sentences: She was part of the cast of JD Lawrence's stage play Rumors, as the character Michelle.
section: == Acting career ==

sentences: She hit the road from January 31, 2008 to March 2, 2008.
section: == Acting career ==

sentences: Luckett was also the star of the movie Preacher's Kid, which was released in January 2010.
section: == Acting career ==

sentences: She appeared in the movie Killers, released June 4, 2010, along with Ashton Kutcher, Katherine Heigl, Tom Selleck and Usher.
section: == Acting career ==

sentences: Luckett then finished shooting the 2011 movie From the Rough, alongside Taraji P. Henson and Tom Felton.
section: == Acting career ==

sentences: For the second season, Luckett was cast in the HBO drama series Treme.

sentences: In 2013, Luckett landed a recurring role on VH1 television series Single Ladies.

sentences: In  2016, she was cast in the second season of Rosewood.
